node.title: Why everyone with a mortgage should be watching the Australian dollar
node.alt: Picture of Australian one dollar coins stacked on top of note currency
node.description: When the Aussie dollar shows signs of moving significantly one way or the other economists take notice. And it's starting to fall, writes David Taylor.
node.content:
["Australia's economy, by international standards is relatively small, but our dollar is among the most traded in the world.", "So when it moves by more than a cent or two (against a major currency like the US dollar), it tends to gain a bit of momentum.", "Throughout much of the second half of this year it's been what's called \"range bound\" \u2014 which means it's struggled to break out of a trading range between 72 and 74 US cents.", "Since early November though, the dollar has been descending from 75.5 US cents and is now hovering around 70 US cents.", "When the dollar shows signs of moving significantly one way or the other, economists take notice.", "
Dollar stakes centre stage
", "So why do we care if the dollar moves?", "Because changes in the dollar influence the prices we pay for imported products, and therefore inflation.", "That is, the lower the value of the dollar, the more of it we need to buy something made in another country.", "\"If it falls 10 per cent, then all things being equal, imported prices rise 10 per cent, and they are about 20 per cent of the CPI, so spread over a year, it would add 2 per cent to prices,\" AMP Capital's Shane Oliver says.", "The dollar has been falling, so if it keeps losing ground, it will add to already existing inflationary pressure.", "And the higher the level of inflation, the more likely it is that the Reserve Bank will bring forward its first increase in the cash rate.", "
How low can it go?
", "There are several factors influencing the dollar's rise and fall.", "They include the price of iron ore, coal and gas (Australia's largest exports);\u00a0the level of Australian interest rates compared to other countries' rates;\u00a0the perceived health of the Australian economy;\u00a0the broad demand for other countries' currencies;\u00a0and, broadly, the level of anxiety on global financial markets.", "Right now commodities prices are under pressure, offshore interest rates are rising, and the pandemic is rattling more than a few nerves on global financial markets.", "", "
The price of iron ore is a key driver of the Australian dollar.\u00a0(ABC News: Rachel Pupazzoni)
", "As such, global currency investors are hoovering up the US dollar as a \"safe haven\" investment and the Australian dollar is slipping.", "There's a realistic chance the dollar could slip below 70 US cents, but it could just as easily stabilise where it is.", "
The good news
", "The good news is that the link between the changes in the dollar and changes in import prices hasn't been as strong in recent times.", "\"It [the dollar] fell about 14 per cent into the pandemic low last year, and inflation didn't fall much,\" Dr Oliver explains.", "\"And by earlier this year, it rebounded to $US0.80, but there was little impact on inflation.", "\"And it partly depends on the ability of companies to pass import price increases onto their customers.\"", "
The bad news
", "The not-so-good news is that the recent fall in the dollar coincides with the unleashing of pent-up consumer demand, according to Dr Oliver.", "Indeed we are already seeing signs inflation is creeping higher, not receding.", "The Melbourne Institute monthly inflation gauge rose by 0.3 per cent in November to be up 3.1 per cent on the year.", "The \"underlying\" or trimmed mean measure also lifted 0.3 per cent to be up 2.6 per cent on the year.", "It only adds to fears the higher inflation we have started to see in the economy is causing consumers to bring forward their spending plans (in fear of paying more for the same item in a few months from now).", "Unfortunately, the resulting boost in demand also fuels inflation.", "", "
Major banks have already begun raising\u00a0their\u00a0fixed-rate mortgages.(ABC News: John Gunn)
", "
One to watch
", "The reality is that if the Australian dollar continues to fall, there's a risk imported inflation, and inflation more broadly, will begin to build.", "Westpac doesn't see that happening. The bank's economics team has the dollar trading at 71 US cents in March and then back down to 70 cents in June.", "The NAB's economics team says \"it takes at least a year\" for a lower dollar to feed through to a materially higher CPI.", "The problem is that the pandemic has thrown most economic models out the window.", "At present, businesses are passing on higher costs of production on to consumers, and fears prices will keep rising are pushing many to bring purchases forward, further fuelling inflation.", "Imported inflation only adds to this.", "And Dr Oliver believes the Reserve Bank won't hesitate to shift its monetary policy in response.", "\"So, if sustained, it could add pressure on the RBA to bring forward its first [interest] rate hike.\"", "
It's a risk
", "And that's the crucial point. A sustained build-up in inflation will\u00a0bring forward a Reserve Bank monetary tightening cycle.", "The major banks have begun raising the interest rates on their fixed-rate mortgages.", "In some case they've worked through three or four tightening cycles in the past few months.", "You can see where this is heading, right?", "Analysts fear a scenario of a falling dollar contributing to higher sustained inflation which sees the Reserve Bank raising the cash rate much earlier than predicted.", "That would push variable rates higher which would further put upwards pressure on fixed rates.", "The hope is that all of this coincides with higher economic growth and falling unemployment, but what if it doesn't?"]
